next_lot.desc: Joy Adamson (née Friederike Victoria Gessner) (Austrian, 1910-1980) Three works on paper (i-iii):

lot_info.sDesc: Joy Adamson (née Friederike Victoria Gessner) (Austrian, 1910-1980) Three works on paper (i-iii)
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
Joy Adamson
(née Friederike Victoria Gessner) (Austrian, 1910-1980)
Three works on paper (i-iii):
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
Joy Adamson (née Friederike Victoria Gessner) (Austrian, 1910-1980)
Three works on paper (i-iii):

(i) Lojasa Leakono
signed 'Joy' (lower left); inscribed 'Lojasa Leakono / Lorokuchu-Loirangai / Samburu' (upper right)
watercolour on paper
51.5 x 34.5cm (20 1/4 x 13 9/16in).
unframed.

(ii) Roba Boru (from a pair of portraits, husband and wife)
signed 'Joy' (lower right); inscribed 'Roba Boru / Wuara, Melka Loni / Boran - Jelitu' (lower left)
watercolour on paper
51.5 x 34.5cm (20 1/4 x 13 9/16in).
unframed.

(iii) Boko Roba (from a pair of portraits, husband and wife)
signed 'Joy' (lower left); inscribed 'Boko Roba / Wuor Melka Loni / Boran Matare' (upper left)
watercolour on paper
51.5 x 34.5cm (20 1/4 x 13 9/16in).
unframed.
(3)
lot_info.footnote_sExtraDesc:
Provanance
Acquired from the artist in the 1950s;
A private collection.

Joy Adamson is best known for her conservation efforts associated with the lioness Elsa. She wrote of these experiences in her 1960 best-seller Born Free and was later portrayed by Virginia McKenna in the Oscar winning 1966 film of the same name.

From 1945 Adamson began to paint the different Kenyan communities and was subsequently commissioned by the British Government to record the twenty-two most important tribes in Kenya.

She also published 'The Peoples of Kenya' 1975 and most of Adamson's work can be found in the collection of the National Museums of Kenya.

unframed.

lot_info.footnote_sExtraDesc:
Donkor's print series Jamestown Masquerade is a collaboration with designer, Allan Davids. They depict black models wearing clothing inspired by costumes traditionally worn to masked balls in the 18th century - Venetian masks, lace, feathers. However, the clothes themselves are made from traditional Ghanaian Kente cloth, handwoven brightly coloured strips of silk and cotton.

The series was inspired by Donkor's love of music from the Classical period (c.1730 to 1820). In these photograph prints, the artist imagines how classical music could translate to his birthplace, Ghana. Donkor describes the figures' costumes as "sculptural pieces", monuments to European and Ghanaian cultural history.

lot_info.sDesc: Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela (South African, 1918-2013) Two lithographs (i-ii)
lot_info.sStyledDesc:
Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela
(South African, 1918-2013)
Two lithographs (i-ii):
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela (South African, 1918-2013)
Two lithographs (i-ii):

(i) The Cell
signed and numbered 'NMandela 56/500' with Nelson Mandela Emboss (lower margin)
lithograph on paper
65.5 x 50.5cm (25 13/16 x 19 7/8in).
framed.

(ii) The Motivation
signed and numbered 'NMandela 34/2500' with Nelson Mandela Emboss (lower margin)
lithograph on paper
65.5 x 50.5cm (25 13/16 x 19 7/8in).
framed.
(2)
lot_info.footnote_sExtraDesc:
Provenance
Belgravia Gallery.

The Cell is accompanied by a certificate of authenticity from Ross McLean Calder Art Publisher, Cape Town 2002.

(i) The Sketch [The Cell] depicts the view into Nelson Mandela's prison cell through the open cell door. The few possessions that prisoners were allowed have been emphasised in colour, as they are symbolic of a link with a reality outside the harsh prison regime. Their meagre possessions typically included letters and photographs of family and friends - pieces of paper that acquired tremendous emotional value to prisoners (text from the Belgravia Gallery catalogue).

(ii) In this piece [The Motivation] Nelson Mandela reflects on the years he spent on Robben Island and gives us a glimpse of his spirit of hope and forgiveness. We get an insight into the way that he viewed the island, as a place where "courage endures in the face of endless hardship" and lets us gain an idea of what these unique pieces of art mean to him. Written in his own handwriting, the Artist's Motivation is a truly personal work (text from the Belgravia Gallery catalogue).

The Window

lithograph

framed.
lot_info.footnote_sExtraDesc:
Provenance
Belgravia Gallery.

The work is accompanied by a certificate of authenticity from Ross McLean Calder Art Publisher, Cape Town 2002.

This sketch depicts a view of Table Mountain through the bars of a prison cell on Robben Island. In fact Table Mountain is not visible from the prison cell windows, however, the view depicted in this piece idealises one that resembled freedom and beauty to Nelson Mandela during his incarceration. 'The Window' is one of the few sketches where colour is used throughout indicating the deep emotional value and meaning which is attached to it by Nelson Mandela. The symbolic signifier is significant in African Culture and it is nowhere more evident than in 'The Window' (text from the Belgravia Gallery catalogue).

lot_info.footnote_sExtraDesc:
Born in The Sudan in 1931, Siddig's career began as a calligrapher for the Publications Bureau in Khartoum. This training impressed the importance of line on Siddiq and would imbue his later artworks with a strong rhythmic energy. Following this, he enrolled in a three year course at the School of Art in Khartoum where he specialised in pottery. In 1957 he was awarded a government grant to study ceramics at the Central School of Art in London.

He eventually settled in England permanently in 1967, where his works were positively received. He was nominated for membership of the Craft Potters Association in the early 1970s, and in 1980 the Victoria and Albert Museum acquired several of his pieces for their collection.

Siddig popularised the use of traditional African pottery techniques within British studio ceramics. His pots are hand built, using the ancient methods of coiling and smoothing. He then burnished the surfaces, rubbing them with a stone. On pots which had already been fired in the electric kiln, he would smoke the surface with a lighted taper of finely rolled newspaper, the flame licking the surface and depositing a thin but delicate mottled pattern.

lot_info.sStyledDesc:
Edoardo Villa
(South African, 1915-2011)
Throne 96 x 71 x 63cm (37 13/16 x 27 15/16 x 24 13/16in).
lot_info.sCatalogDesc:
Edoardo Villa (South African, 1915-2011)
Throne
signed and dated 'E.VILLA 1996' (on reverse lower edge)
painted steel
96 x 71 x 63cm (37 13/16 x 27 15/16 x 24 13/16in).
lot_info.footnote_sExtraDesc:
Provenance
Everard Read Gallery, Johannesburg
Private collection
Bonhams' sale, October 2012, lot 424;
A private collection.

The present lot is one of a series on the same theme that Edoardo Villa executed in 1991, inspired by the organic lines of Jackson Hlungwane's carved wooden thrones. Villa's Throne, however, is a vivid, abstract sculpture composed of curved shapes cut from steel sheets, expressing the union of both traditional African culture and modern European art. As Villa explored this theme, "the sculptures increasingly lost all reference to utilitarian purpose and became place and line, slicing into and floating in space, in some sense akin to the paintings of Miro" (Nel 2005, p.104).

Another Throne from the same series is illustrated in Nel 2005 (p. 105).

Bibliography
K. Nel, Villa at 90, (Jeppestown, 2005)
